newsitem.title: MACEDONIA: Skopje and Belgrade sign $1 billion trade pact.
newsitem.headline: Skopje and Belgrade sign $1 billion trade pact.

text.p: The prime ministers of Macedonia and Yugoslavia signed trade agreements in the Macedonian capital on Wednesday, sealing a pact that the Yugoslav Prime Minister said would be worth $1 billion in its first 12 months.

Macedonian Prime Minister Branko Crvenkovski and his Yugoslav counterpart, Radoje Kontic, signed seven separate documents, including an agreement on customs cooperation and the regulation of rail and air traffic.
"Together, the agreements envisage the exchange (of trade worth) $1 billion over the next year," Kontic told reporters.

The agreements cap a mutual recognition pact that normalised relations between the two neighbours last April, ending five years of animosity in the wake of the violent disintegration of the former Yugoslav federation.
Macedonia split away from the old Yugoslavia in 1991, along with the republics of Slovenia, Croatia and Bosnia.
While both Skopje and Belgrade welcomed the trade accords, diplomats say a border dispute could still be a source of friction. A joint commission is studying the problem.
If Kontic's forecast of $1 billion in official trade is realised, it would restore economic ties to the level that economists estimate existed during war-time sanctions.
In 1992 the United Nations imposed wide-ranging economic sanctions on rump Yugoslavia, consisting of Serbia and Montenegro, over its role in the Bosnian war.
But economists estimate that bilateral trade reached $1.1 billion at the height of sanctions in 1995, about half the pre-sanctions trade which totalled $2.5 billion in 1989.
Kontic said trade across the border added up to $201 in the first six months of this year.
